metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Here are the key legal issues extracted from the document:
• Whether the Trademarks Act permits rectification of a trademark registration post-priority period (i.e., more than three months before filing the rectification petition).
• Whether respondent no.1 has used the impugned trademark in relation to razors and razor blades, as required by Section 47 of the Trademarks Act.
• Validity of registration of trademark DORCO/ bearing registration number 1252224 in respect of razors and razor blades in Class 8.
• Requirements for use of a registered trademark under Section 57 of the Trademarks Act.
• Conditions for cancellation/removal of trademark registration under Section 47, 57 and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999.
• Doctrine of trademark estoppel: whether respondent no.1 is estopped from making claims related to the impugned trademark due to prior use by petitioner.
• Burden and standard of proof in a rectification petition under the Trademarks Act.
• Rights of the trademark owner (petitioner) to challenge registration of a conflicting trademark under the law.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Summary of the Legal Case:**

**Background**

The present rectification petition was filed by Dorco Co. Ltd., a company engaged in the business of manufacturing and exporting grooming products such as shaving razors, blades, kitchen knives, and stationery cutters, against Durga Enterprises and its partner Govind Prasad Bagaria for registration of the trademark DORCO.

**Legal Issues**

The petitioner sought cancellation/ removal of the trademark DORCO under Sections 47, 57, and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999 (hereinafter "Act") alleging that:

1. Respondent No. 1, Durga Enterprises, had not used the registered trademark DORCO for a continuous period of five years from the date of registration in relation to the goods for which the registration was granted.
2. The registration of the impugned trademark was obtained by respondent No. 1 with the dishonest and malafide intention to ride on the goodwill of petitioner Dorco Co. Ltd.

**Arguments**

Dorco Co. Ltd. contended that:

* It had used the trademark DORCO since 1964 in different parts of the world, including India since 1994.
* The respondent No. 1 had not used the registered trademark for a continuous period of five years from the date of registration and was liable to be removed under Section 47(1)(b) of the Act.
* The registration of the impugned trademark was obtained by respondent No. 1 in collusion with petitioner's distributor in Nepal, Mr. Pramod Sureka, with a dishonest and malafide intention.

**Court Findings**

The Court found that:

* Respondent No. 1 had not used the registered trademark DORCO for a continuous period of five years from the date of registration.
* The respondent No. 1 had obtained the registration by colluding with petitioner's distributor in Nepal, Mr. Pramod Sureka.
* There was no genuine use of the trademark by respondent No. 1 and it was being used only to sell razor blades.

**Decision**

The Court held that:

* The registration of the trademark DORCO bearing registration number 1252224 was liable to be removed/ cancelled under Sections 47, 57, and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999.
* The order passed by the Registrar of Trade Marks dated 6th December, 2019 refusing to remove/cancel the impugned trademark was set aside.

The judgment was delivered on March 10, 2023.

metadata.full_text:
--- PAGE 1 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 1 of 7 
 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
 
% 
 
 
 
                 Date of decision: 10th March, 2023 
 
+  
 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022 
 
 
DORCO CO. LTD. 
 
 
 
 
..... Petitioner 
Through: 
Ms. Priya Adlakha with Mrs. Bindra 
Rana and Ms. Rima Majumdar, 
Advocates. 
 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
DURGA ENTERPRISES AND ANR  
 
..... Respondents 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
Mr. 
Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, CGSC 
with Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. 
Sagar Mehlawat and  
Mr. Alexander Mathai Paikaday, 
Advocates for R-1. 
 
 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
 
 
 
 
 
JUDGMENT 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. (Oral) 
 
1. 
The present rectification petition has been filed on behalf of the 
petitioner seeking cancellation/removal of the trademark DORCO/ 
  bearing registration number 1252224 and registered in the 
name of respondent no.1 in respect of razors and razor blades in Class 8 
under Sections 47, 57 and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999 (hereinafter 
„Act‟).  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 2 of 7 
 
 
Case set up by the petitioner 
2. 
The case set up by the petitioner in the petition is as follows:  
2.1 
The petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd., is engaged in the business of 
manufacturing and exporting grooming products such as shaving 
razors, blades, kitchen knives and stationery cutters since 1955. The 
petitioner is Asia's market leader in respect of razors, razor blades, 
kitchen knives and stationery cutters etc. The petitioner is widely 
recognized around the world for introducing the world‟s first 7-blade 
shaving system. The products of the petitioner are sold in 120 
countries around the world.  
2.2 
The petitioner derived the trademark DORCO from the name of its 
company, Dorco Co. Ltd., and has used the said trademark in different 
parts of the world since 1964 and in India since 1994. The petitioner 
is the registered proprietor of the trademark DORCO in India in 
various classes, since 1994 and obtained the first registration of the 
aforesaid trademark on 30th November, 1994 in India. Details of the 
registration of the trademarks of the petitioner are given on page 3 of 
the petition.  
2.3 
In 2015, the petitioner partnered with e-commerce platform „Lets 
Shave‟ to sell its products in India through www.letsshave.com. Since 
then, its products are available for sale on several e-commerce 
platforms in India such as, Amazon, Flipkart, Snapdeal, eBay etc. 
2.4 
The petitioner has also registered domain name www.dorco.in on 13th 
December, 2006, which comprises the petitioner‟s trademark 
DORCO.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 3 of 7 
 
2.5 
The petitioner has also been featured in popular trade magazines and 
newspapers with circulation in India. The petitioner has a strong 
presence on social networking sites such as Twitter, Instagram and 
Facebook. 
2.6 
The respondent no.1 is the partnership firm of one Mr Govind Prasad 
Bagaria and Ms. Rakhi Sureka.  The respondent no.1 got the 
trademark 
DORCO/ 
 
(hereinafter 
„impugned 
trademark‟) registered vide registration no.1252224 in respect of 
razors and razor blades in class 8 in India. The application for 
registration of the impugned trademark was filed on 28th November, 
2003 claiming use since 1st April, 2001.  
2.7 
The respondent no.1 has not used the registered trademark upto three 
months before the date of the present rectification petition, for a 
continuous period of five years from the date of registration, in 
relation to the goods for which the registration was granted. 
Therefore, it is liable to be removed for „non-use‟ in terms of Section 
47(1)(b) of the Act. 
2.8 
The registration of the impugned trademark is obtained by the 
respondent no.1 in collusion with the petitioner‟s distributor in Nepal, 
Mr. Pramod Sureka, with the dishonest and malafide intention to ride 
on the goodwill of the petitioner. Hence, the same is liable to be 
rectified under Sec 57 (2) of the Act. 
2.9 
Vide email dated 27th July, 2016, Mr. Pramod Sureka informed the 
petitioner that Govind Prasad Bagaria was well aware of the rights 
and reputation of the petitioner and its trademark DORCO and its 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 4 of 7 
 
formative marks. However, he demanded Rs. 15,00,000/- to assign the 
impugned trademark back to the petitioner. 
2.10 The partners of respondent no.1 have also applied for registration of 
the trademarks of other international brands such as “Anfanna” and 
“Tarzan Boy”. Hence, the partners of respondent no.1 are habitual 
trademark squatters and serial infringers. 
2.11 Accordingly, the present petition has been filed by the petitioner.  
Proceedings in the suit 
3. 
Notice in the present petition was issued by the Intellectual Property 
Appellate Board (IPAB) on 18th January, 2018. However, the respondent 
no.1 failed to appear before IPAB despite service. Thereafter, the present 
rectification got transferred to this Court after coming into effect of 
Tribunals Reforms Act, 2022 and the Court notice was issued to the 
respondent no.1 by this Court on 25th January, 2022. It is noted in the order 
dated 6th October, 2022 that the respondent no.1 refused to accept notice and 
that the same amounted to service.  
4. 
Subsequently, an application for substituted service was filed by the 
petitioner and the same was allowed and the respondent no.1 was directed to 
be served by way of publication. The affidavit of service has been filed on 
behalf of the petitioner and the same is taken on record. Therefore, the 
respondent no.1 is deemed to have been served. None has appeared on 
behalf of the respondent no.1, nor any reply/counter-statement has been filed 
on behalf of the respondent no.1. It is indicative of the fact that the 
respondent no.1 has nothing substantial to put forth on merits, by way of a 
response to the averments made in the petition.  
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 5 of 7 
 
Analysis and Findings 
5. 
 I have heard the counsels for the parties and perused the record of the 
case.  
6. 
 In order to determine whether the trademark of the respondent no.1 is 
identical to the trademark of the petitioner, it would be apposite to refer to 
the two competing trademarks, as set out below:  
Petitoner‟s Trademarks 
Defendant‟s Trademarks 
 
 
7. 
The impugned trademark was applied for registration by the 
respondent no.1 claiming user since 1st April, 2001. However, upto a date of 
three months before filing the present rectification petition, a period of five 
years have elapsed from the date of registration of the impugned trademark, 
during which there has been no bonafide use of the impugned trademark in 
relation to the goods for which the registration was granted.  
8. 
In the judgment in Shell Transource Limited v. Shell International 
Petroleum Company Ltd.¸ 2012 SCC IPAB 29, it was observed by the 
IPAB that the onus of proving “non-user” is on the person who pleads the 
same. However, when the applicant pleads “non-user”, the respondent must 
specifically deny it. Therefore, in the absence of a specific denial, it was 
held that the allegations of “non-user” stood admitted.  
9. 
In the present case, the allegations of “non-user” against the 
respondent no.1 stand admitted in the absence of a specific denial of the 
same and the impugned trademark is liable to be removed from the Register 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 6 of 7 
 
of Trade Marks on account of “non-user” as contemplated under Section 
47(1)(b) of the Act.  
10. 
From the facts detailed above, it is clear that the petitioner is the 
proprietor of the impugned trademark. The respondent no.1 cannot claim to 
be the proprietor of the impugned trademark as there is nothing to show as 
to how the impugned trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1. 
Therefore, the application for registration of the impugned trademark is in 
contravention of Section 18(1) of the Act. In fact, the registration of the 
petitioner‟s identical mark in respect of similar goods, was pending in India 
and was also cited as a conflicting mark in the examination report issued in 
the application for registration of the impugned trade mark. Therefore, as per 
Sections 9(1)(a) and 11(1)(a) of the Act, the registration of the impugned 
trademark could not be granted. 
11. 
The registration of the impugned trademark is also in contravention of 
Section 11(3)(b) of the Act, as its use would be prevented in India by virtue 
of the law of copyright, as the petitioner is the original owner of copyright in 
the impugned trademark, which is also registered as a trademark in its 
favour in Korea since 2002 and thereafter, in Turkey, China and Ukraine. 
12. 
The grant of registration of the impugned trademark by the respondent 
no.2 is against the principles of Section 11(3)(a) of the Act, as there is no 
dispute that the petitioner is the prior user of the impugned trademark since 
1994 in India and across the world since 1964. Due to such a long, 
continuous and extensive use, the impugned trademark is solely associated 
with the petitioner. Therefore, the registration of the impugned trademark 
should have been refused by the respondent no.2. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 7 of 7 
 
13. 
In view of the discussion above, it is clear that the impugned 
trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1 dishonestly to trade 
upon the established goodwill and reputation of the petitioner and to project 
itself to be associated with the petitioner. The nature of the impugned 
trademark is such that it will deceive the public and create confusion as 
regards the source of the goods manufactured and sold under the impugned 
trademark.  
14. 
Accordingly, the present petition is allowed and the impugned 
trademark registered under trademark application no.1252224 in the name of 
the respondent no.1 in Class 8 is removed from the Register of Trade Marks.  
15. 
 A copy of the order be sent to the respondents through e-mail. The 
Registry is directed to supply a copy of the present order to the Trademark 
Registry, at e-mail - llc-ipo@gov.in for compliance.  
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
MARCH 10, 2023 
at 
 
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary: Dorco Co. Ltd. vs Durga Enterprises and anr**

**Citation:** C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022, Delivered on: March 10th, 2023

**Source:** Section 6 of the PDF document "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf"

**Parties:**

* **Petitioner:** Dorco Co. Ltd.
	+ Through advocates Ms. Priya Adlakha, Mrs. Bindra Rana, and Ms. Rima Majumdar
* **Respondents:**
	+ Durga Enterprises (R-1)
	+ Anr (not specified)

**Background:**

Dorco Co. Ltd. filed a rectification petition seeking cancellation/removal of the trademark DORCO, registered in the name of respondent no. 1, Durga Enterprises.

**Petitioner's Case:**

* Dorco Co. Ltd. has been manufacturing and exporting grooming products since 1955.
* The company is Asia's market leader for razors, razor blades, kitchen knives, and stationery cutters.
* The trademark DORCO was derived from the company name and used globally since 1964 and in India since 1994.
* Dorco Co. Ltd. holds registration of the trademark in various classes in India.

**Key Dates:**

* November 30th, 1994: First registration of trademark DORCO in India.
* December 13th, 2006: Registration of domain name www.dorco.in
* 2015: Partnership with e-commerce platform Lets Shave to sell products in India through www.letsshave.com.

**Judgment:**

The judgment is not provided in this section of the document. Further proceedings and outcome are not specified.

**Summary of Page 1 from PDF "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf"**

Source: 2023/DHC/001821 - C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi has considered a rectification petition filed by petitioner Dorco Co. Ltd. against respondents Durga Enterprises and another.

**Key Facts and Proceedings:**

* The petition seeks cancellation/removal of trademark DORCO bearing registration number 1252224.
* The mark is registered in the name of respondent no.1 in respect of razors and razor blades in Class 8 under Sections 47, 57, and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999.

**Court Details:**

* Date of decision: 10th March, 2023
* Judge: Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal

**Counsel for Parties:**

* Petitioner: Ms. Priya Adlakha with Mrs. Bindra Rana and Ms. Rima Majumdar
* Respondents: Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, CGSC with Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary:
**Case Summary from Dorco vs Durga PDF (PDF Source: 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf)**

In C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022, Dorco Co. Ltd. (petitioner) filed a case against Durga Enterprises and another respondent.

**Key Facts:**

* Date of decision: 10th March, 2023
* Petitioner's business: manufacturing and exporting grooming products since 1955
* Trademark DORCO registered in India since 1994
* Products sold on e-commerce platforms, including LetsShave, Amazon, Flipkart, Snapdeal, eBay, etc.
* Registered domain name www.dorco.in in 2006

**Legal Proceedings:**

The case is ongoing, with the petitioner seeking to protect its trademark and business interests.

**Significance:**

This case highlights the importance of trademark protection and online presence for businesses. The outcome will have implications for e-commerce companies and intellectual property rights.

Please note that this summary only covers the content of page 2 of the PDF.

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Summary of Section "Background and Facts" from Dorco vs Durga.pdf**

This is a High Court of Delhi at New Delhi case (2023/DHC/001821) filed by Dorco Co. Ltd. vs Durga Enterprises and Anr (C.O. COMM.IPD-TM 50/2022). The key points are:

**Facts:**

* Dorco Co. Ltd., the petitioner, has a strong presence on social media and is featured in trade magazines with Indian circulation.
* Respondent no.1, Durga Enterprises, registered the trademark "DORCO" (impugned trademark) for razors and razor blades in class 8 on November 28, 2003, claiming use since April 1, 2001.
* However, respondent no.1 has not used the trademark continuously for five years before filing the rectification petition.

**Arguments:**

* Section 47(1)(b) of the Act states that registration is liable to be removed if not in continuous use for five years; thus, the impugned trademark should be removed due to non-use.
* The registration was obtained by respondent no.1 in collusion with Dorco's distributor in Nepal, Mr. Pramod Sureka, with a malafide intention to ride on Dorco's goodwill.

**Parties and Dates:**

* Petitioner: Dorco Co. Ltd.
* Respondent no.1: Durga Enterprises
* Registration date: November 28, 2003
* Email from Mr. Pramod Sureka to Dorco: July 27, 2016

This summary is based on the PDF file "Dorco vs Durga.pdf"

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 3 from the PDF 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf (Context: 2023/DHC/001821 C.O. COMM.IPD-TM 50/2022):

**Legal Facts and Proceedings**

* The petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd., claims that the respondent, Durga Enterprises, obtained trademark registration in bad faith.
* Respondent No.1's partnership firm registered the trademark "DORCO" (impugned trademark) for razors and razor blades in class 8, India, on November 28, 2003.
* The application claimed use since April 1, 2001.

**Arguments**

* Respondent No.1 failed to use the impugned trademark for the required five years after registration (Section 47(1)(b) of the Act).
* Registration was obtained in collusion with petitioner's distributor in Nepal, Mr. Pramod Sureka, with malafide intent to ride on petitioner's goodwill (Sec 57 (2) of the Act).

**Date and Signatory**

* Email dated July 27, 2016, informed by Mr. Pramod Sureka.
* Digitally signed by AMIT BANSAL on March 14, 2023, 15:05:52, Signature Not Verified.

(Summary from PDF source: 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf)

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
The section "Legal Arguments" from the document 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf refers to a case filed by Dorco Co. Ltd. (Petitioner) against Durga Enterprises and another (Respondents) in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi.

**Facts:**

* The Respondent No.1 attempted to assign the impugned trademark back to the Petitioner for Rs. 15,00,000/-.
* Both Respondent No.1's partners have applied for registration of trademarks on other international brands such as "Anfanna" and "Tarzan Boy".

**Proceedings:**

* Notice was issued by the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) on January 18, 2018 but Respondent No.1 failed to appear.
* The case got transferred to this Court after the Tribunals Reforms Act, 2022 came into effect and a notice was issued again on January 25, 2022.

**Service of Notice:**

* Substituted service was allowed by the Court on an application filed by the Petitioner.
* Respondent No.1 refused to accept the notice but it is deemed served by publication.

**Arguments:**

* Petitioner's Counsel argued that Respondent No.1 cannot claim the impugned trademark as their own due to non-user for over 5 years, violating Section 47(1)(b) of the Act.
* The Allegations of "non-user" against Respondent No.1 stand admitted in the absence of a specific denial.

**Decision:**

* On March 10, 2023, the Court observed that the impugned trademark is liable to be removed from the Register on account of non-user and in the absence of a specific denial.

Source: 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf (PDF document).

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
Page 4 of the PDF 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf (2023/DHC/001821) focuses on the proceedings in the suit:

* The respondent no.1 failed to appear before the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) despite service, and hence, the present rectification got transferred to this Court.
* A Court notice was issued to the respondent no.1 by this Court on 25th January, 2022.
* On 6th October, 2022, it was noted that the respondent no.1 refused to accept notice, which was deemed as service.
* The petitioner filed an application for substituted service, which was allowed, and the respondent no.1 was directed to be served by way of publication.
* An affidavit of service has been filed, and the respondent no.1 is deemed to have been served.
* Since none appeared on behalf of respondent no.1 nor any reply/counter-statement has been filed, it indicates that the respondent no.1 has nothing substantial to put forth on merits.

Source: PDF 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf (2023/DHC/001821)

rectification got transferred to this Court after coming into effect of 
Tribunals Reforms Act, 2022 and the Court notice was issued to the 
respondent no.1 by this Court on 25th January, 2022. It is noted in the order 
dated 6th October, 2022 that the respondent no.1 refused to accept notice and 
that the same amounted to service.  
4. 
Subsequently, an application for substituted service was filed by the 
petitioner and the same was allowed and the respondent no.1 was directed to 
be served by way of publication. The affidavit of service has been filed on 
behalf of the petitioner and the same is taken on record. Therefore, the 
respondent no.1 is deemed to have been served. None has appeared on 
behalf of the respondent no.1, nor any reply/counter-statement has been filed 
on behalf of the respondent no.1. It is indicative of the fact that the 
respondent no.1 has nothing substantial to put forth on merits, by way of a 
response to the averments made in the petition.  
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
Summary of Page 5 from PDF: "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf"

**Case Details:**

* Case Number: C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022
* Date of Decision: 10th March, 2023

**Page Content:**

The High Court of Delhi has heard the counsels for both parties and perused the record of the case.

**Key Findings:**

1. The impugned trademark was applied for registration by Respondent No. 1 in 2001.
2. However, a period of five years had elapsed before filing the rectification petition, during which there was no bonafide use of the impugned trademark.
3. In the absence of a specific denial, the allegations of "non-user" against Respondent No. 1 stand admitted.
4. The impugned trademark is liable to be removed from the Register.

**PDF Source:** "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf"

**Note:** This summary focuses on legal facts and proceedings within the 200-word limit, omitting narrative descriptions and maintaining an objective tone.
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 5 of 7 
 
Analysis and Findings 
5. 
 I have heard the counsels for the parties and perused the record of the 
case.  
6. 
 In order to determine whether the trademark of the respondent no.1 is 
identical to the trademark of the petitioner, it would be apposite to refer to 
the two competing trademarks, as set out below:  
Petitoner‟s Trademarks 
Defendant‟s Trademarks 
 
 
7. 
The impugned trademark was applied for registration by the 
respondent no.1 claiming user since 1st April, 2001. However, upto a date of 
three months before filing the present rectification petition, a period of five 
years have elapsed from the date of registration of the impugned trademark, 
during which there has been no bonafide use of the impugned trademark in 
relation to the goods for which the registration was granted.  
8. 
In the judgment in Shell Transource Limited v. Shell International 
Petroleum Company Ltd.¸ 2012 SCC IPAB 29, it was observed by the 
IPAB that the onus of proving “non-user” is on the person who pleads the 
same. However, when the applicant pleads “non-user”, the respondent must 
specifically deny it. Therefore, in the absence of a specific denial, it was 
held that the allegations of “non-user” stood admitted.  
9. 
In the present case, the allegations of “non-user” against the 
respondent no.1 stand admitted in the absence of a specific denial of the 
same and the impugned trademark is liable to be removed from the Register 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 6 from the PDF "Dorco vs Durga.pdf" (2023/DHC/001821):

**Legal Facts and Proceedings**

* The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi is hearing the case C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022, where Dorco Co. Ltd. (petitioner) is challenging the registration of a trademark by Durga Enterprises (respondent).
* The petitioner claims that the respondent cannot claim ownership of the impugned trademark as there is no evidence to support its adoption.
* The application for registration of the impugned trademark is in contravention of Section 18(1) of the Trade Marks Act.

**Sectional Analysis**

* Sections 9(1)(a), 11(1)(a), and 47(1)(b) of the Act are relevant to this case, which pertain to non-use and registration of conflicting trademarks.
* The petitioner's identical mark was registered in India and cited as a conflicting mark in the examination report.

**Source:** PDF "Dorco vs Durga.pdf" (2023/DHC/001821), specifically Page 6.
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 6 of 7 
 
of Trade Marks on account of “non-user” as contemplated under Section 
47(1)(b) of the Act.  
10. 
From the facts detailed above, it is clear that the petitioner is the 
proprietor of the impugned trademark. The respondent no.1 cannot claim to 
be the proprietor of the impugned trademark as there is nothing to show as 
to how the impugned trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1. 
Therefore, the application for registration of the impugned trademark is in 
contravention of Section 18(1) of the Act. In fact, the registration of the 
petitioner‟s identical mark in respect of similar goods, was pending in India 
and was also cited as a conflicting mark in the examination report issued in 
the application for registration of the impugned trade mark. Therefore, as per 
Sections 9(1)(a) and 11(1)(a) of the Act, the registration of the impugned 
trademark could not be granted. 
11. 
The registration of the impugned trademark is also in contravention of 
Section 11(3)(b) of the Act, as its use would be prevented in India by virtue 
of the law of copyright, as the petitioner is the original owner of copyright in 
the impugned trademark, which is also registered as a trademark in its 
favour in Korea since 2002 and thereafter, in Turkey, China and Ukraine. 
12. 
The grant of registration of the impugned trademark by the respondent 
no.2 is against the principles of Section 11(3)(a) of the Act, as there is no 
dispute that the petitioner is the prior user of the impugned trademark since 
1994 in India and across the world since 1964. Due to such a long, 
continuous and extensive use, the impugned trademark is solely associated 
with the petitioner. Therefore, the registration of the impugned trademark 
should have been refused by the respondent no.2. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
Here is a summary of the court decision from Section "Court Decision" of PDF file **6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf**

**Case Details:**

* Case Name: C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022
* Petitioner: Dorco Co. Ltd.
* Respondents: Durga Enterprises and Another (Durga)
* Context: Trademark dispute (2023/DHC/001821)

**Court Decision:**

On March 10, 2023, the Hon'ble High Court of Delhi at New Delhi delivered its decision in favor of Dorco Co. Ltd.

**Facts and Arguments:**

* The respondent, Durga Enterprises, had registered a trademark (Application No. 1252224) similar to Dorco's established trademark.
* It was alleged that Durga adopted the trademark dishonestly to trade upon Dorco's goodwill and reputation.
* The court observed that the impugned trademark would deceive the public and create confusion regarding the source of goods.

**Decision:**

The High Court allowed the petition (C.O. 50/2022) and ordered:

* Removal of the impugned trademark registered in the name of Durga Enterprises from the Register of Trade Marks.
* A copy of the order to be sent to the respondents through email.

**Other Directives:**

* The Registry was directed to supply a copy of the present order to the Trademark Registry for compliance.

Note: No amount is mentioned in the provided document.

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
Here is the summary of page 7 from the PDF source "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf":

**Case Details:**

* Case Number: C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022
* Date of Decision: 10th March, 2023
* Judge: Amit Bansal, J.

**Decision:**

* The impugned trademark registered under Trademark Application No.1252224 in the name of Respondent No.1 is removed from the Register of Trade Marks.
* The trademark was adopted dishonestly to trade upon the established goodwill and reputation of Petitioner Dorco Co. Ltd., creating confusion among the public.

**Order:**

* A copy of the order will be sent to the respondents through email, and the Registry is directed to supply a copy of the present order to the Trademark Registry for compliance.
* The decision is allowed in favor of Petitioner Dorco Co. Ltd.

Source: "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf", page 7 of 7.
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 7 of 7 
 
13. 
In view of the discussion above, it is clear that the impugned 
trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1 dishonestly to trade 
upon the established goodwill and reputation of the petitioner and to project 
itself to be associated with the petitioner. The nature of the impugned 
trademark is such that it will deceive the public and create confusion as 
regards the source of the goods manufactured and sold under the impugned 
trademark.  
14. 
Accordingly, the present petition is allowed and the impugned 
trademark registered under trademark application no.1252224 in the name of 
the respondent no.1 in Class 8 is removed from the Register of Trade Marks.  
15. 
 A copy of the order be sent to the respondents through e-mail. The 
Registry is directed to supply a copy of the present order to the Trademark 
Registry, at e-mail - llc-ipo@gov.in for compliance.  
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
MARCH 10, 2023 
at

BANSAL
